official-title.#text:
To amend title 10, United States Code, to make certain
		  improvements in the Uniform Code of Military Justice related to sex-related
		  offenses committed by members of the Armed Forces, and for other
		  purposes.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced
			 the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Better Enforcement for Sexual
			 Assault Free Environments Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the
The table of contents of this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.

Sec. 2. Limitations on convening authority discretion regarding
				court-martial findings and sentence.

Sec. 3. Mandatory discharge or dismissal for certain
				sex-related offenses under the Uniform Code of Military Justice and trial of
				such offenses by general courts-martial.

Sec. 4. Elimination of five-year statute of limitations on
				trial by court-martial for additional offenses involving sex-related
				crimes.

Sec. 5. Consideration of need for, and authority to provide
				for, temporary administrative reassignment or removal of a member on active
				duty who is accused of committing a sexual assault or related
				offense.

Sec. 6. Victims’ Counsel for victims of sex-related offenses
				committed by members of the Armed Forces and related provisions.

Sec. 7. Secretary of Defense report on sentencing
				reform.

Sec. 8. Secretary of Defense report on role of commanders in
				military justice process.

header.#text:
Limitations on
			 discretion regarding court-Martial findings

text.#text:
Action on the findings of a court-martial
				by the convening authority or by another person authorized to act under this
				section is not required.

If a convening authority or other person
				acts on the findings of a court-martial, the convening authority or other
				person may not—

dismiss any charge or specification,
				other than a charge or specification for a minor offense, by setting aside a
				finding of guilty thereto; or

change a finding of guilty to a charge or
				specification, other than a charge or specification for a minor offense, to a
				finding of guilty to an offense that is a lesser included offense of the
				offense stated in the charge or specification.

If a convening authority or other person
				acts on the findings to dismiss or change any charge or specification for a
				minor offense, the convening authority or other person shall prepare a written
				explanation of such action. Such written explanation shall be immediately
				provided and made a part of the record of the court-martial at the time the
				action is taken and becomes effective.

For purposes of this paragraph, the
				convening authority or other person may treat an offense as a minor offense
				only if the sentence adjudged by a court-martial for an offense, or combination
				of offenses, is not more severe than confinement for 30 days, forfeiture of
				two-thirds pay per month for one month, or reduction to the lowest pay grade,
				or some combination thereof. However, a charge or specification of murder,
				rape, sexual assault, rape or sexual assault of a child, or any other offense
				punishable by death may not, under any circumstances, be considered a minor
				offense for purposes of this paragraph, regardless of the adjudged
				sentence.

If a mandatory minimum sentence exists for

				than the mandatory minimum sentence, except that, upon the recommendation of
				the trial counsel, the convening authority or other person shall have the
				authority to impose a sentence below a level established by statute as a
				minimum sentence so as to reflect the substantial assistance by the accused in
				the investigation or prosecution of another person who has committed an
				offense.

header.#text:
Victims'
				Counsel for victims of sex-related offenses committed by members of the armed
				forces

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, the Secretary concerned shall designate
				legal counsel (to be known as

, who is the victim of a sex-related offense,
				regardless of whether the allegation is restricted or unrestricted.

text.#text:
Under regulations
				prescribed by the

The types of legal
				assistance contemplated by this subsection may include the following:

Legal consultation regarding potential
				criminal liability of the victim stemming from or in relation to the
				circumstances surrounding the alleged sex-related offense and the victim’s
				right to seek military defense services.

Legal consultation
				regarding the Victim Witness Assistance Program (VWAP), including—

the rights and
				benefits afforded the victim;

the role of the
				Victim/Witness Advocate or Liaison and what privileges do or do not exist
				between the victim and the Advocate or Liaison; and

the nature of
				communication made to the Victim/Witness Advocate or Liaison as opposed to
				communication made to the Legal Assistance Attorney.

Legal consultation
				regarding the potential for civil litigation against other parties (other than
				the

Legal consultation
				regarding any proceedings of the military justice process that the victim may
				observe.

Legal consultation
				regarding the military justice system, including—

the Government’s
				authority to compel cooperation and testimony; and

the victim’s
				responsibility to testify, and other duties to the court.

Accompanying the
				victim at any proceedings in connection with the reporting, military
				investigation, and military prosecution of the alleged sex-related
				offense.

Legal consultation
				regarding—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and other State and Federal victims’ compensation programs; and

text.#text:
eligibility for
				and requirements for obtaining any available military and veteran benefits,
				such as transitional compensation benefits found in

the availability
				of, and any protections offered by, civilian and military restraining
				orders.

Legal consultation
				and assistance in personal civil legal matters in accordance with

Such other legal
				assistance as the Secretary concerned may specify under this subsection.

An
				individual may not be designated as a Victims’ Counsel under this section
				unless the individual is—

a judge advocate
				or a civilian attorney serving as a legal assistance attorney who is a graduate
				of an accredited law school and is a member of the bar of a Federal court or of
				the highest court of a State; and

is certified as
				competent to be designated as a Victims’ Counsel by the Judge Advocate General
				of the Armed Force of which the individual is a member.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
) under the jurisdiction of the Secretary, and within the Marine
				Corps the Staff Judge Advocate to the Commandant of the Marine Corps, is
				responsible for the establishment and supervision of individuals designated as
				Victims’ Counsel.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, who is the
				victim of an alleged sex-related offense shall be provided assistance by a
				Victims’ Counsel upon report of an allegation of a sex-related offense or at
				the time the victim seeks assistance from a Sexual Assault Response
				Coordinator, a Sexual Assault Victim Advocate, a military criminal
				investigator, a victim/witness liaison, a trial counsel, a healthcare provider,
				or any other personnel designated by the Secretary concerned for purposes of
				this subsection. The assistance of a Victims’ Counsel under this subsection
				shall be available to a member or a dependent regardless of whether the member
				or dependent elects unrestricted or restricted reporting of the sex-related
				offense. The member or dependent shall also be informed that the assistance of
				the Victims’ Counsel is an option and may be declined, in whole or in part, at
				any
				time.
